Award.AwardTitle: Polypeptide Hybrid Particles and Their Constituents
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

Some of nature's most important building blocks and functional engines are made of proteins. Synthetic polypeptides, which can be made in large amounts by simple methods, borrow the protein structure and retain many protein-like features, such as the ability to rotate light and respond to thermal or chemical changes in the environment. The problem is that, even though they are very large molecules, polypeptides are still very small things. This makes them hard to manipulate. This project marries the functionality of bio-inspired polypeptides to the easy manipulation of larger particles using gravitational or magnetic fields. This will be accomplished by placing the polypeptides onto colloidal silica, essentially little balls of glass, resulting in core-shell particles. By adjusting the temperature, the shape of the polypeptide shell will be altered. This will provide information on shape transitions similar to those used e.g. by influenza virus to penetrate the human body. Chains of particles crosslinked by the action of light will result in nearly uniform filaments that bring polymer science into the visible regime for easier inspection, while facilitating the creation of even larger structures. Studies on a particularly attractive water-soluble polypeptide will lead to improved understanding of the kinds of polymers used to make high-strength fibers, such as those woven into bullet-proof vests. New educational and outreach initiatives are incorporated, integrated with real-world experience and laboratory research.


TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

These research activities will develop and explore submicron particles having synthetic polypeptide shells atop silica cores, sometimes with magnetic inclusions. The polypeptide shells render the particles responsive to temperature and good sensors of molecular asymmetry, while the silica cores make it possible to direct these functions to a particular location. Whole particles and their individual polypeptide and silica components will be studied. Specifically, the following work will be performed: 1) The effects of core radius, shell polymer coverage, and shell polymer molecular weight on a thermally driven coil-to-helix transition will be assessed by small-angle X-ray and neutron scattering, static and dynamic light scattering, optical rotatory dispersion, and NMR; 2) The particles, acting as very large monomers, will be polymerized into nearly uniform chains by using a magnetic field to align them perpendicular to a striped optical pattern that will initiate a photochemical crosslinking reaction originally developed for proteins; 3) Better understanding of silica core structure, including newly discovered variants, will be achieved by chromatography with fractionation and scattering of X-ray or visible radiation; 4) The stiffness of a water-soluble, uncharged polypeptide will be determined by combined chromatographic and scattering methods; 5) A big difference between the mobility of rigid rods and polypeptide semiflexible filaments will be explored by an optical tracer method; 6) A long-standing problem with the measurement of rigid rod diffusion using pulsed-gradient NMR will be re-assessed using a very high-field-gradient facility.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Introduction: Polypeptides are polymers based on the underlying motif nature uses to make proteins. The special properties of polypeptides include optical activity to control light, chirality to select and separate molecules of defined shape, and chemical versatility to permit attachment of a wide range of molecules for sensing the presence of other molecules or for carrying payloads such as therapeutic agents. Because they can fold into several different conformations, polypeptides also display size and shape responsiveness to stimuli that can generate mechanical force. The problem is that polypeptides, though large as molecules go, are still much too small to manipulate. Placing them (and their functionality) in a given location is difficult.

Intellectual Merit: This project investigated how the special properties of polypeptides can be joined to the easy manipulation of colloidal particles.Polypeptides were placed on the surface of silica particles, either by growing them from the surface or by attaching them in ready-made form. Chains of particles were formed by application of a magnetic field and crosslinked by action of visible light. These chains can be developed into uniform filaments that will bring polymer science into the visible regime, amenable to study by optical microscopy. Not only that, but the very stiffness of the bonds between the particle "monomers" can be varied. Additionally, these chains will facilitate the creation of even larger structures. In order to understand polypeptides attached to colloidal particles, it helps to understand the polypeptide and particle components separately. To that end, a nuclear magnetic resonance technique (not too different from that used in MRI medical imaging) was used to understand how polypeptides move when dissolved in solution. The importance of solution properties is magnified by the fact that polypeptides and other stiff polymers are normally processed into useful materials from solutions, rather than from melts as is the case of many standard commercial polymers. 

Broader Impacts: In a technical sense, making it possible to control where polypeptides and their myriad functional properties go can lead to new delivery vehicles for pharmaceuticals. Linking the particles into poly(colloids) leads to new structural materials that respond to inputs such as temperature change or acidity. By mixing the particles with liquid crystals, science can go beyond mere self-assembly and enter a new regime where the surroundings participate in assembly. The human side of this project is embodied in the commitment to service displayed by its participants. The theme has been to explore the role of non-profit helper organizations that assist with education and technology. One of these, the Applied Polymer Technology Extension Consortium, operates in the economically challenged south-central US, fostering greater understanding of polymer science and connecting industrial partners with the academic enterprise. A second non-profit organization, the Chemical Educational Foundation, operates a "quiz bowl" for middle school students. In the coming year, it is expected that nearly 100,000 students in 44 states will participate. The winner from each state, plus parents and a teacher, are brought to Washington DC for the national competition, an inspiring event which also features workshops to further advance the teaching of chemistry. Students supported by this program participated by vetting questions used in the quiz bowl, assisting with workshops, and attending the national competition as ambassadors and, it is hoped, future supporters.
